title: Monday, 26th October, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

This is Markets Live

PM

And this is a warning: we do have a problem with comments, across FT.com. If it flares up during this ML session we will be down for 15/20 mins before the systems are re-set

11:01 am
PM

If if flares up

PM

it might now

PM

We might well be fine

11:02 am
PM

And on that note, we should get on

I stand corrected ! -- ex-Globo

PM

But let me just give you a flavour

11:04 am
PM

Of stuff we ahve to deal with in the background

PM

Shield your eyes, children

Dictum meum pactum22 hours ago
Globo: lots of sales, fewer partners | FT Alphaville
Paul Murphy taxgift45 **NT SCUM ROT IN HELL WITH EBOLA

BE

Cripes!

PM

How's that for creative abuse

BE

Not enough to rot in hell. Ebola too. That's quite a kicker.

11:06 am

Stuff like that get's binned automatically and the commenter get's banned

But just have a read thru the stuff in the comments stream here

http://ftalphavill...es-fewer-partners/

PM

PM

Any more stuff you want to send to the editor?

PM

The "press counci"

PM

The police?

BE

That's always the way of these things. People always shout "shenanigans" when told what they don't want to hear, then melt into the furniture.

BE

(@mike: no I didn't.)

PM

(Johnd -- not from taxgift -- the abuse was in reply to that commenter)

11:08 am
BE

(@Mike: in fact, I don't even remember saying anything about it. Do you have a link?)

BE

So, to catch up on the news this morning..........

BE

Turns out the CEO was cooking the books.

11:09 am
BE

And fessed up in an "emergency" board meeting.

BE

After the Quintessential short report, which mostly raised the same points as all the other short reports on Globo over the years.

BE

Such as -- selected entirely randomly -- the one from TheAnalyst in 2013.

11:10 am
BE

Brief extract.

BE

BE

That's from its July 2015 update.

11:11 am

So given all these v v v aggressive attacks over recent years...

BE

(And I hope they don't mind me reproducing it here. It's advertising if nothing else.)

PM

Might have expected the noddies, the chairman, the brokers, the auditors, the bankers

11:12 am
PM

And so on

PM

To have looked under the bonnet?

PM

No

11:12 am
PM

Or is that asking too much

PM

It actually to Dan McCrum to start asking questions and verifying all the stuff in the QCM report

PM

That finally flushed this out

11:13 am

here's the chairman

PM

BE

(@TheLeggie: it's had several auditors, though none for long.)

11:13 am

Ex Netscape i think

PM

Barry M. Ariko

Non-exec chairman, so he's on the hook for failing to ask any questions at all.

11:14 am

BDO resigned as auditors, yeah -- and the non-exec's didn't think to ask "why"

BE

You know Mr Ariko was a non-exec at Autonomy beftween 2000 and 2010?

BE

Just saying.

11:15 am
PM

censored

PM

better check what other boards he on

BE

And I think he was "special advisor" at the time of the HP takeover.

11:15 am
BE

Otherwise, not much in the way of listed company experience.

BE

For listed experience you want Gavin John Burnell

BE

Mr. Gavin John Burnell is Non-Executive Chairman at Goldcrest Resources Plc, a Managing Director & Director at Hot Rocks Investments Plc, a Managing Director & Director at Hellenic Capital Plc, a Managing Director at Woodland Capital Group Plc, Non-Executive Chairman at Magnolia Petroleum Plc, Non-Executive Chairman at Sports 1st Ltd., and a Director at Elephant Oil Ltd. He is on the Board of Directors at Prospex Oil & Gas Plc, Hot Rocks Investments Plc, Globo Plc, Hellenic Capital Plc, Rift Resources Plc, Charlie's Agents Ltd., Elephant Oil Ltd., and Lizzy Bet Ltd.

Mr. Burnell was previously employed as Non-Executive Director by Sula Iron & Gold Plc, Non-Executive Director by Agricola Resources Plc, a Principal by Ruegg & Co. Ltd., Non-Executive Director by Fairholt Resource Investments Plc, Non-Executive Director by Iceni Oil & Gas Ltd., Non-Executive Director by Israeli Acquisitor I Plc, Non-Executive Director by Agneash Soft Commodities Plc, Non-Executive Director by North American Petroleum PLC, Non-Executive Director by Silvrex Ltd., and Non-Executive Director by Stratex International Plc.

"Hot Rocks Investments Plc"

Who seem to have been terribly unlucky with clients.

11:17 am

hehehe

11:18 am

omg smile omg smile

Who replaced Kevin Ashton. See posts passim for details of that.

11:19 am

@TheLeggie: you're right to correct me, past tense. Was broker.

Though there's also something called Forum Venture Capital and Forum European Smallcaps, which have about 11 per cent in total.

11:22 am

PM

11:23 am

Not only did he sell a load, he also put a bunch out on loan

And the loan has now defaulted

BE

With this counterparty: http://lantauholdingsltd.com/

11:23 am

Which offers up to 75% LTV.

Trousered cash

PM

So think it's fair to say Konstantios is now a wanted man

11:24 am
BE

Uh, yes. It would be unsurprising if the cash is now in a suitcase being loaded onto a direct flight to Rio.

PM

Will add one nugget to this: Dan called Konstantios on Wednesday last week. We then didn't actually publish until Friday, when the stock was suspended

PM

I suspect Dan's call crystalised Konstantios thinkins as to what was going to happen next

11:25 am
PM

Dan's gonna do a timeline a bit later today

BE

Once he fessed up to the board, I'm wondering if there's a fiduciary duty on the non-execs to lock the doors and phone the police.

BE

It's not something I remember coming up before. But it's an interesting test case.

11:27 am
BE

Anyway, we should probably turn to other matters. Stocks that might ever actually trade again, for instance.

undefined
PM

So, welcome back Bryce

So we are not giong to push it

Well, it's an unusual story.

PM

Welcome

BE

11:32 am

So we're going to park this one. Too many people dissing

From a great height

TalkTalk

How slow is the market on this one?

11:33 am
Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 233.97, down 22.83 (-8.89%), High: 260.00, Low: 231.70, Volume: 4.62m
PM

yeah, the stock was off 5/6% on Friday

PM

But it\'s only now that people are realising how serious the thing is

11:33 am
BE

It's a digital Macondo. Market's delayed realisation that the company's lost control of its problem.

PM

Yep exactly

BE

Note this statement that came out on Saturday.

11:34 am
BE

Current status.

Following our announcement on 22 October 2015 of the significant and sustained Cyber Attack on 21 October 2015, and launch of a criminal investigation by the Metropolitan Police, the current status of our investigation is as follows:

- This cyber attack was on our website not our core systems

- We can confirm that we do not store complete credit card details on the website; any credit card details that may have been accessed had a series of numbers hidden and therefore are not usable for financial transactions eg 012345xxxxxx 6789

- TalkTalk My Account passwords have not been accessed

- We now expect the amount of financial information that may have been accessed to be materially lower than initially believed and would on its own not enable a criminal to take money from your account

- The Metropolitan Police Cyber Crime Unit criminal investigation continues

BE

Now, I assume that's genuine.

BE

Though I've no way of knowing, really. It was just an email, and as a former TalkTalk customer who knows who now has my email address.

11:35 am
PM

hahaha, yes!

BE

However, assuming it is genuine, it seems the problem is a lot less severe than initially reported.

BE

Which is no longer the point. The company didn't know immediately (or didn't admit immediately) that it was hacked .......

11:36 am
BE

..... Then it didn't know to what extent it'd been hacked.

BE

Then it fluffed all subsequent responses, and now finds it can't stuff the toothpaste back in the tube.

BE

Saying, "actually, we screwed up and didn't lose as much as we thought, don't worry" would sound complacent.

11:37 am
BE

They've made, apologies for the profanity, an absolute arse of this.

PM

Very good

BE

(@sans: I wasn't working that day, but understand the website as DDOS'd so it was clear they had an issue.)

11:39 am
PM

(taxgift45 -- there's no suggestion you wrote the abuse. Its a clear response to stuff written by you and me -- written by Dictum meum pactum )

PM

(But I will remove it from this transcript at the end of the sessions just to be clear)

BE

Should also note the Times has reported that TalkTalk customers have said their bank accounts had been cleared out and overdrawn.

11:40 am
BE

Dunno. Correlation - causation.

BE

(@TRC: overwhelming a server with requests. I wrote the first article in the mainstream press about DDOS attacks, since you asked.)

BE

Anyway, nothing to say in terms of sellside.

11:42 am
BE

Reputation damage here is unquantifiable.

BE

And as noted previously, it takes no time whatsoever to change your internet provider.

BE

You don't even need to tell TalkTalk you're leaving. Just sign up with someone else.

11:43 am
undefined
BE

Can we do some sellside? I'm tired of typing.

PM

Suer

11:44 am
PM

Sure even

PM

WPP?

PM

They are top of the Foosie fallers

11:44 am
PM

Q3s

PM

a bit disappointing

BE

Thought the figures were in line.

11:45 am
BE

Ditto guidance.

PM

Here's Steve Liechti Investec

PM

3Q LFL slightly below forecasts, but FY guidance is unchanged subject to 4Q re-budgeting. Add – we like the growth shift to digital/EM and cash generation, but see some unhelpful near-term global GDP uncertainty, e.g. EM macro/FX. Forecasts UR but not expected to change materially pre-meeting though we will tweak geographic assumptions given 3Q trends, better expected EM in 4Q and softer 4Q group comps. We are roughly in line with FY15 FactSet consensus. CY16E adj EV/EBITDA 11x, P/E 14.4x, FCF/div yield 7.3%/3.4%.

11:45 am
PM

Outlook – Still reiterating FY LFL targets of over +3% LFL and cc margin +0.3% pt.s. However, WPP is yet to formally review its 4Q budgets and tends to be cautious at this time of year despite easier comps. 9M cc margin is strong at +0.5% pt.s, but guidance remains +0.3% for the FY. We note the reported 9M margin is +0.3% so a -0.2% FX hit. We have a FY15E reported margin of +0.2% pt.s.
3Q NET LFL sales +3.3% vs f/c +3.7% (1H +2.3%). Within this, digital is +7% and we note good new biz at £3.2bn in 9M vs our ‘norm’ of $1bn/quarter. We currently forecast FY15/16E LFL at +3.2%/+3.8%. Note that comps are easier in 2H and 4Q – FY14A net sales per quarter were 3.8%, 4.4%, 3.0% and 2.1%.
NET LFL sales by geography – N. America +3.7% vs f/c +5% (1H +2.8%) so better than 1H, but not as good as we hoped. Ad/Media, direct, digital and interactive and specialist are performing well (we f/c FY15E +4%). UK +2.2% vs f/c +4.7% (1H +2.8%) so a lot slower with Ad/Media, data IM and healthcare soft but PR/public affairs and direct, digital and interactive strong (we f/c FY15E +4%). C. Europe +4.6% vs f/c +0.6% (1H +1.2%), so much better. Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and Turkey are strong, but Greece and Ireland slower (we f/c FY15E +0.9%). EM is +2.4% vs f/c +3.6% (1H +2.3%) so below f/c. Australia, China, Philippines better, but Indonesia and Malaysia slower (we f/c FY15E +3.2%). EM (particularly Asia Pac/Latam) is expected to outperform mature markets in 4Q.
3Q LFL by vertical – Ad/Media +3.7% (1H 3.2%), PR +4.5% (1H +1.6%), Spec Comms +4.3% (1H +2.4%) were good, but Data IM is still flat.

PM

And Shore

PM

WPP (WPP, No Rec, 1480p) - Q3 IMS. WPP has published an IMS updating on Q3 and the nine months to end September 2015. This statement indicates that the robust performance reported at the interim stage has been sustained. Revenue for the first nine months of the year increased by 6.9% YoY on a constant currency basis (4.8% LfL) and there was an encouraging 0.5% margin improvement. Like for like net sales growth was achieved across all geographies and operating segments Net new business of $3.2bn was achieved during Q3 ($5.1bn YTD) consolidating the co’s industry leading position. £588m of stock was been bought back YTD (3.0% of issued equity)and 38 acquisitions completed – primarily focused on reinforcing the group’s position in faster growing regions and digital media disciplines. Outlook comments suggest a robust performance for the year as a whole, despite a sensible degree of caution on Q4. Significantly (and apparently in contrast to the sentiment within last week’s update from Publicis), results from the previously reported upsurge in client review activity across the industry are described as “highly satisfactory” with major retentions and wins recorded and limited losses.

(@alewis2005: it won't come out of suspension until it can provide accurate figures. And without a broker it has one month before delisting. You'd be brave to think it can get accurate figures together inside 31 days.)

undefined
PM

We've run out of things to talk about

11:51 am
BE

Hm. Feeling a bit out of the loop post a few days off.

BE

Quite a good note out of investec on the oil explorers.

BE

Only change is downgrading Cairn

11:51 am
Cairn Energy PLC (CNE:LSE): Last: 152.00, down 2.1 (-1.36%), High: 152.60, Low: 150.10, Volume: 280.29k
BE

Also pro Genel, which hasn't been a brilliant trade.

Genel Energy PLC (GENL:LSE): Last: 279.00, up 0.25 (+0.09%), High: 288.25, Low: 276.00, Volume: 227.62k
11:52 am
BE

Here's the gist of it.

BE

This can get worse! Valuations still assume higher oil prices and the prevailing investment narrative for the sector is survival. The former is by no means guaranteed, while the latter is unlikely to attract fresh investment. Therefore, in order to avoid a long derating, a more positive narrative must now emerge. We appreciate that this is easier said than done, but if finding resources does not become the central theme of the sector again, valuations will continue to drift. To reverse this negative inertia, tough deals (at realistic prices!) need to be delivered. Unbalanced capital structures also need to be rebalanced. This will require pragmatism but, in our view, those that can offer something more than just survival now have the best chance of being rewarded further down the road.

BE

The Buys – It’s not all bad! We upgrade Amerisur (TP 31p), integrating CPO-5 upside into our RENAV. Circle Oil (TP 23p) represents deep value, but new management must demonstrate how they intend to realise this value. Genel (TP 445p) trades close to the risked value of Taq Taq and Tawke, which seems extreme with Kurdish payments starting to emerge. Ithaca (TP 65p) has already shown the rewards on offer for pragmatism through its recent Petrofac and Delek deals. Finally, we view the prevailing cynicism that surrounds Ophir’s (TP 115p) operations in Equatorial Guinea and Tanzania as stale and see risk/reward now skewed towards a more constructive, but heavily risked, stance.

11:53 am
BE

The Sells – We downgrade Cairn (TP 130p) to Sell (from Hold), seeing a balanced risk/reward as it heads into its Senegal appraisal programme. We also see little wiggle room in its cash flow dynamics through to 2017E for unexpected surprises. We maintain our Sell on Tullow (TP 195p) with the capital structure continuing to undermine existing equity holders. More disappointingly, its broader narrative now represents little more than a leveraged bet on oil.

BE

The Holds – Both SOCO (TP 190p) and Wentworth (TP 35p) show positive cashflow growth, but are also fully valued in our view.

BE

Oil price methodology – We base our price assumptions on the forward curve for liquid exchange traded commodities. Where other oil & gas products are sold regionally or into different markets, future price assumptions base pricing on available data sources, company information or exchange traded forward prices where available. Future prices comprise Year 1, Year 2, Year 3 and Long-term. Year 1 is the current year (2015) and therefore combines a weighted average of the historical spot prices and future price for the remaining year’s balance. On this methodology, our new Brent 2015, 2016, 2017 and Long Term oil price assumptions are $55/b (previously $60/b), $55/b (previously $60/b), $60/b and $65/b (previously $70/b). Our new WTI 2015, 2016, 2017 and Long Term oil price assumptions are $50/b (previously $55/b), $55/b (unchanged), $55/b and $60/b (previously $65/b).

11:54 am
BE

On Majestic ...............

BE

The six-bottle limit finally goes, after years of discussing the possibility.

PM

Very significant surely

11:55 am
BE

It is. Majestic becomes a big Oddbins

BE

And Oddbins failed ..... So .......... Um ...................

Majestic Wine PLC (MJW:LSE): Last: 347.31, down 7.69 (-2.17%), High: 353.00, Low: 346.25, Volume: 65.04k
11:56 am
BE

"strategically sensible" says Liberum

BE

(MJW LN) The company has announced the launch of a new pricing proposition, both in store and online, including the removal of the 6 bottle minimum spend rule. The proposition is designed to make shopping simpler for new and existing customers.

Over Christmas, deals for customers buying any 6 wines and spirits will include: (i) at least 10% off and up to 33% off, (ii) money back guarantee if customers are not satisfied with products, and (iii) free delivery and glass hire.

We see these steps as strategically sensible. The removal of the 6 bottle minimum spend rule comes after successful trials in selected stores. We do not see any changes to numbers here as the costs of these initiatives is captured within the company’s guidance. We expect to hear details on further initiatives when the company provides its strategy update at its interim results on 16th November.

BE

We've questioned before the reason for Majestic to exist.

11:57 am
BE

As in, it offers six bottles of stuff the customer doesn’t recognise at a 20% discount

BE

Which is a difficult proposition against the supermarkets, which also offer unknown brands at a 20% discount without the multi-bottle minimum.

BE

Resulting in several profit warnings and a strategic review that seemed to take about a year.

12:04 pm

http://prisonconsu...about-us/the-team/

PM

Our consultants, both male and female, have experience of prison life from ‘behind the door’, They are graduates of the prison system, ex offenders who are able to offer words of wisdom based on real experience.

PM

We are here to help you help you through the whole legal process including any court appearance or prison sentence that this may result in. If you do go to prison we are here to help you and your family through what will be a traumatic experience. We shall help and advise you prior to any custodial sentence and shall be available for the duration of any sentence.

Our consultants hold qualifications in Counselling or are Samaritan trained listeners. We shall not judge you, and if you request it, we need not discuss your case history. We sincerely hope that your circumstances do not result in you having to serve a prison sentence. We are simply here to help you and your family through what shall initially be a traumatic change in life style. We shall help and advise you prior to a custodial sentence and shall be available for advice for the duration of your term. We can also offer advice and guidance to your family and friends as they come to terms with and engage with your period in prison. We are on hand to offer advice and guidance to your coping with and managing prison life. We are Prison Life Coaches.

12:05 pm

PM

12:05 pm
